title: 108_s2205
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk directly.

Summarized chunk:
"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Summarized chunk:
The Congress finds that Ukraine allows its citizens the right to emigrate with minimal taxes, has been compliant with freedom of emigration requirements since 1997, and has made progress towards democracy and a free-market economy since 1991. Ukraine has taken important steps towards creating democratic institutions and a free-market economy, committing to developing governance in line with human rights principles. Progress has been made in meeting international standards in recent Parliamentary elections, despite remaining shortcomings in implementing election laws and allegations of interference. Ukraine has made progress in recent Parliamentary elections, despite shortcomings in implementing election laws and allegations of interference. As a participating state of the OSCE, Ukraine is committed to addressing issues related to national and religious minorities. Ukraine has enacted legislation to protect against incitement to violence based on discrimination. Ukraine has enacted legislation to protect against incitement to violence based on discrimination, including anti-Semitism. It has also committed to ensuring freedom of religion and combating racial and ethnic intolerance. Additionally, Ukraine is cooperating with US NGOs to combat ethnic and religious intolerance and is working on restitution of religious properties confiscated from minorities during the Soviet era. Ukraine is developing a legislative framework to return confiscated properties to minority groups, cooperating with US NGOs to combat intolerance, and making progress towards joining the World Trade Organization. Ukraine is addressing various issues to join the World Trade Organization, including commitments on agricultural products, intellectual property rights, tariff reductions, trade in services, agricultural subsidies, export incentives, and customs reform. The country has enacted labor rights protections but gaps remain in enforcement. Ukraine has committed to respecting freedom of the press as an OSCE member, despite ongoing infringements. Ukraine, as an OSCE member, has committed to respecting freedom of the press despite ongoing infringements. The country has positive relations with neighboring countries and aims for European integration, democracy, and prosperity for its citizens. Ukraine has also cooperated with the United States in peacekeeping operations in Europe and the fight against international terrorism. SEC. 2. TERMINATION OF APPLICATION OF TITLE IV OF THE TRADE ACT OF 1974 TO UKRAINE. The President may determine that title IV should no longer apply to Ukraine and extend permanent normal trade relations treatment to the country's products. Upon extension, chapter 1 of title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 will cease to apply to Ukraine. The Congress urges Ukraine to fulfill its commitments as an OSCE member, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, combating discrimination and violence, restoring religious properties, and upholding media freedoms. The Congress urges Ukraine to work on restitution of communal properties, respect media freedoms, improve in various areas, protect intellectual property rights, resolve trade disputes quickly, and monitor human rights and rule of law with US assistance. The United States continues to monitor human rights, rule of law, and media freedoms in Ukraine, providing assistance to NGOs and human rights groups. Annual discussions are sought with Ukraine on these issues, involving US and Ukrainian NGOs. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. The reports required by sections 102(b) and 203 of the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 shall include an assessment of certain issues. SEC. 5. CONTINUED ENJOYMENT OF RIGHTS UNDER THE JUNE 23, 1992, BILATERAL TRADE AGREEMENT. SEC. 5. The trade agreement between the United States and Ukraine from June 23, 1992, remains in force, granting the U.S. rights to use safeguard rules against import surges from Ukraine. Section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974 applies to Ukraine as it does to China as long as the agreement is in force. The President must notify Congress within 5 days of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession. A report on the agreement must be transmitted to Congress within 15 days. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced within 30 days of the notification, it will be considered. Section 154(b) of the Trade Act of 1974 states that a resolution of disapproval regarding the US-Ukraine agreement on WTO accession can be considered by Congress within 30 days of notification by the President. The US-Ukraine agreement on WTO accession, notified to Congress, does not advance US interests. Resolutions of disapproval can be introduced in the House of Representatives and referred to the Committees on Ways and Means and Rules, without amendments. The US-Ukraine agreement on WTO accession can be subject to resolutions of disapproval in the House of Representatives and the Senate. In the House, it is referred to the Committees on Ways and Means and Rules without amendments, while in the Senate, it is referred to the Committee on Finance and cannot be amended. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions on committee discharge and floor consideration apply to resolutions of disapproval regarding the US-Ukraine WTO accession agreement. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate govern the enactment of such resolutions. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate govern the enactment of resolutions, with the constitutional right of either House to change the rules relating to procedures at any time.
